# Draft:Soomra–Ghurid War

The Soomra–Ghurid War was a conflict between the Soomra dynasty of Sindh and the Ghurid dynasty. The war took place in two areas: northern Sindh (Jacobabad) and Debal.
It resulted in a decisive Soomra victory which made Ghurid rule in Sindh impossible.
Background
During the rule of Sultan Umar I Soomro, the Ghurid invasion of Sindh occurred. Sultan Umar I died in 1181, and Samsudulah Dodo ascended the throne. Dodo III resisted the Ghurids and made their rule impossible.
The Battle
The Soomras, under Samsudulah Dodo II, attacked the Ghurid forces in Debal and Jacobabad.
They defeated the Ghurid troops and secured Sindh once again.
Aftermath
The Ghurid invasions of northern Sindh and Debal, which had started during the reign of Sultan Umar I Soomro, were repelled.
The defeat made Ghurid expansion into Sindh impossible.
